title: COVID-19 eviction moratoriums in the United States
text:
In response to the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>, the <a href="Federal%20government%20of%20the%20United%20States">United States federal government</a> and several <a href="United%20States">U.S. states</a> implemented moratoriums on <a href="eviction">eviction</a>.
Federal.
In March 2020, the <a href="United%20States%20Congress">United States Congress</a> passed the <a href="CARES%20Act">CARES Act</a>, which included a moratorium on the evictions of tenants in rental properties that receive federal funding or have federal government-backed mortgages until July 2020.
The <a href="Centers%20for%20Disease%20Control%20and%20Prevention">Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</a> (CDC) announced an additional eviction moratorium on September 1, expected to last until December 31 of that year. The order cited Section 361 of the <a href="Public%20Health%20Service%20Act">Public Health Service Act</a>, which gives the agency authority to:
A challenge to the moratorium was filed in November by the Alabama Association of Realtors. In the <a href="United%20States%20District%20Court%20for%20the%20District%20of%20Columbia">District Court for D.C.</a>, Judge <a href="Dabney%20L.%20Friedrich">Dabney L. Friedrich</a> ruled that the Public Health Service act did not give the CDC authority to enact moratoria on evictions. Friedrich cited the rule of "<a href="eiusdem%20generis">eiusdem generis</a>", writing that evictions were too dissimilar from the other items listed in Section 361 to be covered under the phrase "and other measures." On appeal, the <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20the%20United%20States">Supreme Court</a> voted 5–4, to maintain the moratorium.
The <a href="Biden%20administration">Biden administration</a> issued a new eviction moratorium on August 3, 2021, intended to last until October 3. It was applicable to counties with substantial or high transmission rates of COVID-19. On August 26, the Supreme Court struck down the moratorium.
State.
43 <a href="U.S.%20state">U.S. states</a> have implemented some form of an eviction moratorium during the COVID-19 pandemic; 27 of these states lifted their eviction moratoriums between May and September 2020.
California.
On June 28, <a href="Governor%20of%20California">Governor</a> <a href="Gavin%20Newsom">Newsom</a> signed a bill passed by the <a href="California%20State%20Legislature">California State Legislature</a> extending eviction protections until September 30.
New York.
In December 2020, the <a href="New%20York%20State%20Legislature">New York State Legislature</a> passed a state moratorium on evictions. In May 2021, the legislature extended the moratorium until August 31.
The Supreme Court struck down a provision of the state moratorium that protected people who filed a form declaring economic hardship, rather than providing evidence in court.
